headline: Fareed Zakaria GPS
subHeadline: Why Iran Hates America. Aired 8-9p ET

utterances.speaker: ERIN BURNETT, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Surprise attack by Hamas.

utterances.speaker: JAKE TAPPER, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: By land, by air, and by sea.FAREED ZAKARIA, CNN ANCHOR (voice-over): October 7th, 2023 was a day that changed the world.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Terrorist attack by Hamas.UNIDENTIFIED MALE (through text translation): We are the mighty people, the people of Gaza.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: A brutal surprise attack by Hamas in Israel.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Israel is firing back.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Was followed by a horrific retaliation in Gaza. Now there are fears of a wider war, and America has a target on its back.

utterances.speaker: MAX FOSTER, CNN INTERNATIONAL ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Iran-backed rebels struck a U.S. owned ship.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: At the center of the fears of a wider conflict is Iran. It is linked to Hamas. To Hezbollah. To the Houthis. All part of its axis of resistance.Why is Iran at the center of this conflict in so many ways? And why this relentless hostility to America? To answer those questions, we need to go back decades and try to understand, WHY IRAN HATES AMERICA. (END VIDEOTAPE) ZAKARIA (on-camera): Good evening. I'm Fareed Zakaria. Iran in the United States shared deep psychic and emotional scars going back years but none is remembered more by Americans than the hostage crisis of 1979. We watched what appeared to be an irrational, furious attack and wondered why or how anyone would act this way. But to Iran, taking the hostages was completely rational given the history that led up to that moment. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) ZAKARIA (voice-over): In November 1979 Iranian students stormed the U.S. embassy in Tehran, turning it into a prison for American embassy staff. The young revolutionary spent months in the embassy's basement trying to piece together evidence of past American misdeeds. Why? Because decades earlier, that basement was where American and British spies had plotted a coup against what had long been a close ally. SEYED HOSSEIN MOUSAVIAN, AUTHOR, "THE IRANIAN NUCLEAR CRISIS": Iran and the U.S. from 1850 to 1950 had the best relations.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The man seen here shaking hands with President Harry Truman in 1951 was Iran's prime minister, Mohammad Mosaddegh.

utterances.speaker: ABBAS MILANI, STANFORD UNIVERSITY
utterances.sentences: He was very adept at the theater of politics. He was a great orator. He was incorruptible.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: For years, Mossadegh had complained about the agreement that had given the British control of Iran's oil resources.

utterances.speaker: KARIM SADJADPOUR, GEORGETOWN UNIVERSITY
utterances.sentences: The vast majority of revenue for Iranian oil would go to the British government, not to the people of Iran. There was probably almost 90-10.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But in a momentous decision, the parliament voted to nationalize the oil industry then elected Mossadegh as prime minister one month later.

utterances.speaker: MILANI
utterances.sentences: As soon as he nationalized the oil, the British decided that they want to overthrow him. The Truman administration has stopped them, and said, no, this has to have a diplomatic solution. So from '51 to '53, there is an effort by the U.S. to broker a diplomatic agreement between the British and Iran.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE) along with U.S. Ambassador Grady Sanders seeks to end the oil dispute between Britain and Iran.

utterances.speaker: MILANI
utterances.sentences: The agreement never materialized.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The United States was in the early years of tensions with the Soviet Union, the Cold War. Among their battles for supremacy the two superpowers were fighting for dominance in the Middle East.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Oil deposits underlying Iran soil gave the Soviet premier good reason for him designs on this militarily helpless nation.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Washington's Russian embassy throws a lavish shindig, but most important guest present is the premier of Iran, Mohammad Mosaddegh.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The U.S. was determined to keep communism out and to keep Iranian oil flowing to the Western world. So the British and the Americans plotted to take down Mosaddegh.It was plotted in the British and American embassies.

utterances.speaker: JASON REZAIAN, THE WASHINGTON POST
utterances.sentences: The British worked with agents of the CIA, a grandson of Teddy Roosevelt, Kermit Roosevelt, to undertake a coup against this government.ZAKARIA (voice-over): The U.S.'s involvement in the coup is detailed in government documents that Malcolm Byrne shared with me at the non- profit National Security Archive where he is deputy director and director of research. And these are documents that are original U.S. government documents written at the time, classified, and through a variety of means you have managed to get them either declassified or some reporter essentially got them leaked.

utterances.speaker: MALCOLM BYRNE, NATIONAL SECURITY ARCHIVE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: That's what these documents are?

utterances.speaker: BYRNE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Part three, covert action.

utterances.speaker: BYRNE
utterances.sentences: Covert action.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: This is the coup. So Eisenhower approves it 11 July 1953. The prime minister of England approves it 1 July 1953.

utterances.speaker: BYRNE
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's amazing.ZAKARIA (voice-over): Key to the plot was convincing Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, the monarch who ruled Iran, to personally take action to oust Mosaddegh.

utterances.speaker: MILANI
utterances.sentences: August 15th, at midnight, soldiers knock on Mosaddegh's door and deliver a letter to him, dismissing him from the role of the prime minister. In the morning he goes on the radio. He says there was a coup attempt against me.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Mosaddegh refused to accept his dismissal from office and fought back.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: And on his orders, troops occupied the Shah's palaces and surrounded parliament.

utterances.speaker: MILANI
utterances.sentences: The Shah, who was waiting to see what happens, flees Iran immediately. On August 19th, the tide turns against Mosaddegh.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Former premier Mosaddegh's ruined house is a mute testimony to three days of bloody rioting culminating in a military coup, a Shah who had fled to Rome comes home backed by General Zahidi, military strongman, who engineered his returned to power.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: After the coup succeeded Mosaddegh was convicted of treason, sentenced to prison, than spent the rest of his life under house arrest. As for the Shah --

utterances.speaker: ALI VAEZ, GEORGETOWN UNIVERSITY
utterances.sentences: He started consolidating power, becoming more and more of an autocrat.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Iran's democratic experiment was over. Throughout the decades of the Shah's reign, Iran kept a very good relationship with Israel.ROBIN WRIGHT, AUTHOR, "ROCK THE CASBAH": They traded oil. That kind of relationship between a Muslim country and Israel was very important.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Just as important to America was continuing to limit Soviet influence inside Iran.

utterances.speaker: SADJADPOUR
utterances.sentences: The United States are worried that in countries like Iran where there was enormous wealth disparity, it was going to empower communism because people would see this wealth disparity and say, there should be equality. And so for that reason the U.S. government pushed the Shah to enact these different reforms. Basically trying to promote more economic equality and gender equity inside Iran.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The White Revolution, as it was known, was not universally embraced in Iran. One of the most vocal critics was a Shia cleric and future leader of another revolution, Ruhollah Khomeini.

utterances.speaker: SADJADPOUR
utterances.sentences: He resented the land reform which was going to take land away from the clergy and he in particular resented any gender equality.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Khomeini's rhetoric would help foment wider dissent that led to rioting. Government forces eventually quashed the riots and imprisoned Khomeini before exiling him.(END VIDEOTAPE) ZAKARIA (on-camera): The Shah remained pro-Western, surrounding himself with an elite class that was Western educated and oriented. Many of his admittedly progressive reforms created friction with Iran's more conservative Muslim population. And then there were many who are bitter about not benefiting from the White Revolution reforms. What's more, there was growing resentment of the Shah's lavish lifestyle, which was epitomized by one extravagant party in 1971. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Could a generalist in Iran there to criticize his majesty?

utterances.speaker: MOHAMMAD REZA PAHLAVI, FORMER SHAH OF IRAN
utterances.sentences: He could, but I don't think that he would.

utterances.speaker: REZAIAN
utterances.sentences: And his secret police, the SAVAK, were brutal. hundreds, thousands of Iranians were executed and disappeared.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Yet the Shah's mistreatment of his citizens did not deter thousands of Americans who enjoyed living in Iran.

utterances.speaker: WRIGHT
utterances.sentences: I first went to Iran in 1973. There were casinos, fashion was at its height. It was a place where an American felt very comfortable.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: A place where an American president Jimmy Carter would give this toast on New Year's Eve.JIMMY CARTER, 39TH PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Iran, because of the great leadership of the Shah, is an island of stability in one of the more troubled areas of the world.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Before long, that illusion of stability would be shattered. In December 1978, throngs of protesters demanded the removal of the Shah and the return of Ruhollah Khomeini. Five weeks later, the Shah and his family fled to Egypt. It's a day Abbas Milani remembers well.

utterances.speaker: MILANI
utterances.sentences: On that day I want to see what's happening in the streets. There was joy in the street. People were passing around images of Khomeini.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Then they got the real thing. With Khomeini's return to Iran.

utterances.speaker: WRIGHT
utterances.sentences: Watching Khomeini step off the plane and he was so mobbed they actually had to kind of scurry him off.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Still, there was unrest. The U.S. embassy was attacked. And although this time the mob eventually left, it was a harbinger of what was to come eight months later after President Jimmy Carter allowed the now exiled Shah of Iran to come to the U.S. for cancer treatment.

utterances.speaker: MILANI
utterances.sentences: The Shah had kept his sickness a secret. So some suspicion began to grow that the cancer issue is excused.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Iranians did not believe the Shah was ill and worried that the U.S. would return him to power. VAEZ1979. The fact that the popular government of Mohammad Mosaddegh was toppled through a British and American coup created fears in 1979 that the U.S. would try to do the same thing and admitting the Shah into the U.S. was the trigger for the revolutionaries to try to prevent that from happening by taking hostages.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: People forget that the trigger for the taking of the U.S. embassy was a very specific decision that Jimmy Carter made.(Voice-over): In October 1979, President Jimmy Carter agreed to admit the Shah to the United States for cancer treatments.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: The Shah of Iran is in a New York City hospital tonight. An American government source in Washington says the deposed Iranian monarch is suffering from cancer and a blocked bile duct.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But the Iranians did not believe the Shah was sick. They had another more sinister theory.

utterances.speaker: BYRNE
utterances.sentences: There was a big fear among the revolutionaries that the United States and the Shah might try to pull another coup.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: A coup that would involve the U.S. placing the Shah back in power and putting an end to the revolution. Iranian students took over the U.S. embassy in Tehran to look for direct proof of the American plot, and to demand that the U.S. extradite the Shah to stand trial for what they considered were his crimes against the Iranian people.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And if President Carter does not release the Shah, you're going to fight?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes. We have to fight.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Nearly six months into the hostage crisis the U.S. launched "Operation Eagle Claw," a covert mission to rescue the 52 hostages, which ended in a devastating crash. Eight U.S. service members lay dead in the Persian desert.

utterances.speaker: BYRNE
utterances.sentences: A humiliation for the American people, hopelessness for the hostages.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: For Khomeini and his disciples, the failed rescue attempt was a divine victory and further proof that the Americans could not be trusted.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Although the Iranians had been caught completely by surprise, they capitalized on the failure of the raid.

utterances.speaker: BYRNE
utterances.sentences: Some of their leaders could not resist lording it over the Americans.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: While Iran's religious hardliners were dead set against influence from the West, Iran's moderates had been moving their country towards democracy with the support of much of the population.

utterances.speaker: WRIGHT
utterances.sentences: The overwhelming sense of the day of the revolution was that this was the beginning of a democratic era.

utterances.speaker: MOUSAVIAN
utterances.sentences: A democracy system based on Islamic values.

utterances.speaker: SADJADPOUR
utterances.sentences: An there were individuals that people hoped could emerge as leaders of a democratic country.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: One such leader was a popular moderate who was appointed to be first prime minister of the provisional government. His named, Mehdi Bazargan. And later the moderate, Abolhassan Banisadr, became the Islamic Republic's first president.The two were devout Muslims and advocates of Islamic democracy, human rights, and social justice. But it did not take long for Khomeini and his religious hardliners to turn against this liberal vision.

utterances.speaker: JOHN LIMBERT, FORMER DEPUTY ASSISTANT SECRETARY OF STATE FOR IRAN
utterances.sentences: They were not going to let this provisional government turn Iran into a secular democratic state.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Khomeini used the hostage crisis and the showdown with the United States to isolate and sideline the new provisional government.

utterances.speaker: MILANI
utterances.sentences: To consolidate authoritarianism and tilt the country even further against the U.S., and it was very Machiavellian about it.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Prime Minister Bazargan, who was opposed to the hostage- taking, recognized that the momentum was with Khomeini, and he resigned shortly after the embassy was seized. President Banisadr was impeached in June, 1981.

utterances.speaker: SADJADPOUR
utterances.sentences: A philosopher king who would guide society and tell people how to live according to Islamic values.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Khomeini and his new government ruthlessly consolidated their power. Targeting officials from the Shah's former administration.VALI NASR, AUTHOR, "THE SHIA REVIVAL": Revolutions eliminate the old order by putting it to the sword.

utterances.speaker: SADJADPOUR
utterances.sentences: It's oftentimes the individuals who are most effective in mobilizing violence who prevail, and Khomeini was that person in Iran.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: And if he calls you to fight a holy war, what will you do?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I'll lead.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: But how will you do it? Do you have the weapons?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes, we have,

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Khomeini created revolutionary committees to purge key figures accused of being enemies of the revolution.

utterances.speaker: NASR
utterances.sentences: They all wanted to eliminate all the top bureaucrats, technocrats, political appointees, political activists, journalists who were accused of being close to the monarchy.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Armed citizen militias were organized, empowered to carry out summary justice. A revolutionary court was established to adjudicate cases in a bogus legal system.

utterances.speaker: SADJADPOUR
utterances.sentences: The newfound revolutionary government under Khomeini was really in the business of retribution, not justice.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The Western press dubbed the notorious head of the court, the hanging judge, who swiftly declared individuals guilty and sentenced many to death. After the purge of the monarchists, Khomeini turned on the leftists and socialists. There was imprisonment, torture, and public hangings, firing squads, mass executions, and forced confessions.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Hundreds of arrests and executions not only of Mujahideen, but also of Marxist-Leninist and Maoist, monarchists and members of ethnic and religious minorities.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Iranian exiles estimate up to 30,000 people were killed during that country's period of repression.

utterances.speaker: SADJADPOUR
utterances.sentences: This created an atmosphere of terror among Iranians who quickly had buyers' remorse. They started to realize that this new revolutionary government was going to be far more brutal than the government, which they helped to overthrow.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Overnight, everyday Iranians lost their freedoms and were forced to conform to Khomeini's radical brand of Islam. SADJADPOURIran. How you can dress, what you can eat, what you can drink, what music you can listen to, what movies you can watch, whether you can go out with your boyfriend or girlfriend. Same-sex relationships became a capital offense. A big part of the cultural revolution in Iran was the role of women.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Under Khomeini, women were relegated to a life of, quote, "motherly duty."

utterances.speaker: SADJADPOUR
utterances.sentences: All of a sudden, women weren't allowed to show their hair. They had to cover their bodies and that really was an obsession for the Islamists. In some ways, the hijab, the mandatory veiling of women, became the flag of the Islamic Republic, you know, the chief way to distinguish post-revolutionary Iran from pre-revolutionary Iran.

utterances.speaker: NASR
utterances.sentences: Marriage, divorce, custody of children, and the like. Inheritance. They all became sort of much more favorable to men in accordance to religious law.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: A special police force was established to enforce Islamic laws.

utterances.speaker: SADJADPOUR
utterances.sentences: They set up these morality police. They could raid people's, to check and see if there was alcohol, to check and see if they are watching contraband movies or reading contraband books. And they could essentially arrest and intimidate people at will.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Many of these laws and their effects still exist in Iran today.

utterances.speaker: VAEZ
utterances.sentences: Look, I think if you had portrayed the reality of Islamic Republic today to people who were on the streets in 1979, the revolution would not have succeeded.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Weeks of hit and run border clashes between Iran and Iraq have now erupted into full-scale war.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: September 1980. Iran's next-door neighbor, Iraq, launches an invasion.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: It's pretty clear that the Iraqis do control the port and a good part of the town.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The brain child of its brutal dictator, Saddam Hussein. Saddam had recently become president of Iraq and launched a merciless purge of his rivals. He hoped to become the leader of the entire Arab world. His first move, conquer Iran. With its vast resources of oil. Saddam was smelling blood.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: There was a triumphant and tumultuous welcome in Tehran today for the Ayatollah Khomeini.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The Islamic Republic was weak less than a year old. And much of its military brass had been wiped out by Ayatollah Khomeini who feared a coup.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Iraqi troops pushed 20 miles into Iran.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: As the Iraqis poured over the border, the young Iranian regime faced an existential threat. But eight years and hundreds of thousands of deaths later --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Rage far as the eye can see, martyred for Khomeini and the revolution.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Iran had survived.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: The tide of the war has turned sharply against Iraq.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Withstanding all that Saddam and the West could throw its way.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: The Ayatollah turned the conflict into a crusade for God.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: It was that war that made Iran. That taught its current leaders valuable lessons. Never be outgunned.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Hezbollah has been supported by Iran.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Never be alone in the world.

utterances.speaker: NIC ROBERTSON, CNN INTERNATIONAL DIPLOMATIC EDITOR
utterances.sentences: Iran-backed Houthis.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And always think twice about giving up the ultimate trump card. Nuclear weapons.

utterances.speaker: VAEZ
utterances.sentences: The Iran-Iraq war was certainly the most formative experience that most of the Iranian leadership has had.

utterances.speaker: WRIGHT
utterances.sentences: We think of Iran as aggressive, which it has been. But from the Iranian perspective, they believe they are reacting to the aggression of others.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Saddam Hussein's forces vastly outmatched Iran and captured a major border city soon after invading.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: The main city of Khorramshahr does now seem to have fallen into Iraq.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But surprisingly --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Iraq thought Iran would be a pushover.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The fledgling Iranian regime held firm. Led by their newly formed Revolutionary Guard.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Thousands of young Iranians have taken up arms against the Iraqis.

utterances.speaker: NASR
utterances.sentences: Guerrilla warfare by young revolutionary volunteers.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: With the regular army, chaotic and demoralized, the Iranians had to rely on this likely armed but fanatical militia.

utterances.speaker: NASR
utterances.sentences: They use very unconventional methods, including almost like kamikaze attacks against Iraqi positions.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Iraq doesn't have enough friends to keep its supply.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Iran was utterly isolated.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Because of fears it will export its fanaticism.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Backed only by Syria and Libya among Arab nations.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Iraq is getting everything it needs.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Iraq had most Arab states' support as well as that of the Soviet Union.

utterances.speaker: WRIGHT
utterances.sentences: It was really Iran standing alone against the rest of the world. And it has defined its security strategy ever since.

utterances.speaker: LIMBERT
utterances.sentences: Our support of Saddam Hussein during their Iran-Iraq war I think was disgraceful. ZAKARIAcities.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Iraq is believed to be firing 10 missiles for every one of Iran.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Raining hell fire on civilian populations.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: He says he's 17 years old, his boyish face suggests otherwise.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Meanwhile, the outmatched Ayatollah was sending untrained men and boys to fight, sometimes even without weapons.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: 25,000 Iranian soldiers squared off against Iraqi tanks and artillery. A few hours later, only 250 Iranians were alive.NARGES BAJOGHLI, AUTHOR, "IRAN REFRAMED": This is one of the primary reasons they developed a ballistic missiles program.

utterances.speaker: VAEZ
utterances.sentences: There's a long historical memory of how vulnerable Iran could be at moments of weakness.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: The latest battlefield for chemical weapons.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Then Iran experienced a nightmare.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: The display of civilian victims of an Iraqi poison gas attack.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Saddam's unconscionable attacks with chemical weapons. Thousands suffered a horrific demise.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: This is the true face of a regime that very unfortunately the United States administration is supporting.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The West knew about the strikes and did little to stop them. U.S. intelligence may even have helped Iraq hit its targets.

utterances.speaker: MILANI
utterances.sentences: The decision not to stand up to Saddam Hussein for his use of chemical weapons I think was a very costly mistake. And it helped the Iranian regime to have a moral upper hand. Every time the Iranian regime has done something egregious to its own people or in the region, they say, but what about Saddam Hussein? How come you didn't do anything about Saddam Hussein?

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Iran also feared Saddam's nuclear ambitions. A fear shared by Israel when it struck an Iraqi reactor.The Shah of Iran had been pursuing the bomb. The Islamic Revolutionaries had actually ended the program.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: The deadly nerve gas had been found on Gulf battlefields.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But all of that changed in the Iran-Iraq war.

utterances.speaker: VAEZ
utterances.sentences: Iran decided to relaunch the Sha's nuclear program.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Iran has enriched uranium particles to nearly 84 percent.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And decades later, Iran is frighteningly close to becoming a nuclear power.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Potentially produce a nuclear bomb in less than two weeks.

utterances.speaker: MILANI
utterances.sentences: If Saddam Hussein had been justifiably punished for the use of chemical weapons, the conflagration might have been different. The consequences were profound.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: The exact hour of the ceasefire where mosques comes the call to prayer. Special prayers for peace.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The war ended in a bloody stalemate with little gained but a million casualties. But Iran had survived its baptism by fire.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: The Ayatollah Khomeini's pledge to defeat the superpowers with the power of faith.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The war and its heroes are now part of its law.

utterances.speaker: REZAIAN
utterances.sentences: And murals of fallen soldiers are everywhere in the country.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And today's senior officials, many of them veterans of the war, have applied its lessons, with its arsenal of missiles.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: This is video showing a helicopter belonging to Houthi rebels.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Its proxy forces. Keeping conflict away from Iran's borders.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Iran has made astounding nuclear progress.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And its most feared deterrent nearly achieved. A nuclear program that can be weaponized.GEORGE W. BUSH, 43RD PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: On my order --

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Coming up.

utterances.speaker: BUSH
utterances.sentences: Coalition forces have begun striking selected targets.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Nearly five months after 9/11, President George W. Bush went on the offensive in his 2002 State of the Union Address.

utterances.speaker: BUSH
utterances.sentences: North Korea is a regime arming with missiles and weapons of mass destruction. Iran aggressively pursues these weapons and exports terror. Iraq continues to plan its hostility toward America and to support terror. States like these and their terrorist allies constitute an Axis of Evil arming to threaten the peace of the world.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: A presidential threat branded three countries as the Axis of Evil. And we all know what happened next.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Air raid sirens blared before dawn in Baghdad.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: The first American Marines had moved in.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: March 2003, U.S. forces invade Iraq vowing to destroy its weapons of mass destruction, and put an end to Saddam Hussein's dictatorial rule.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Goodbye, Saddam.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But it was all a historic mistake.DAVID KAY, FORMER U.S. WEAPONS INSPECTOR: It turns out, so we were all wrong.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: There were no weapons of mass destruction. And the invasion set off a firestorm of violence and vitriol, stoking anti-American sentiment throughout the Middle East.

utterances.speaker: BAJOGHLI
utterances.sentences: Iran sees itself as a part of the Axis of Evil. So it begins to feel that it has to create a defensive policy against a potential attack.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: So Iran shifted to its axis of resistance. A forward defense policy that has been its protector for more than 40 years. Iran became a major presence in Iraq, arming Shiite militias that viciously attacked American soldiers. When almost all U.S. troops withdrew in 2011, those militias became an integral part of Iraq's army.

utterances.speaker: SADJADPOUR
utterances.sentences: One of the things which the Islamic Republic has managed to do is to mobilize proxy forces.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Iran was a Persian Shiite Islamic nation facing a sea of Sunni Islamic Arab states backed by America. So it cobbled together a coalition of allies many of them non-Sunni throughout the region.

utterances.speaker: SADJADPOUR
utterances.sentences: The best example of that was the advent of Lebanese Hezbollah, a byproduct of Israel's 1982 invasion of Lebanon. WRIGHTmilitia so the Iranian Revolutionary Guards created the embryo of what became Hezbollah, the party of God. (END VIDEOTAPE) ZAKARIA (on-camera): Iran exploited the chaos during times of crisis and conflict, and built an empire of proxy forces across the Middle East. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) ZAKARIA (voice-over): In Lebanon groups like Hezbollah, the crown jewel of Iran's forward defense policy. In Gaza, Hamas and Islamic Jihad largely responsible for the October 7th attack on Israel. In Yemen, the Houthis who have conducted missile strikes to disrupt shipping lanes and global trade. In Syria, a paramilitary group called Shabiha, organized by President Bashar al-Assad. And in Iraq and Syria, Shia militias. They all act as a conduit and an enforcer to convey Iran's message to the world.

utterances.speaker: NASR
utterances.sentences: Iran would recruit, train, organize these militia groups who had a strategic and a tactical relationship with Iran. They will receive funding for military weaponry and they would also be integrated into a command-and-control structure of the Quds Force.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Quds Force is the most elite part of Iran's Revolutionary Guard responsible for growing the axis of resistance. That task fell on the broad shoulders of notorious Quds Force commander Qasem Soleimani, who took great offense at Bush's Axis of Evil label.

utterances.speaker: BYRNE
utterances.sentences: Here was a person who is just hated by the West and by American officials because he has been the leader of most efforts that have involved threats to the United States.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: A rocket attack on the Baghdad airport kills Iran's most revered military leader.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: When the U.S. assassinated Soleimani in 2020, the result might have backfired, galvanizing Iran and its allies.

utterances.speaker: BAJOGHLI
utterances.sentences: It was actually in many ways a goldmine because instead of him being killed by someone in ISIS he's being assassinated by the great Satan.
